SENT.plain: The traditional presentation of spontaneous internal carotid artery dissection includes ipsilateral hemicranial headache, oculosympathetic paresis, and contralateral focal cerebral ischemic deficits
However, we describe two cases with multiple cranial nerve involvement ipsilateral to the dissection as the principal feature
The first patient, a 36-year-old man, had involvement of the 9th, 10th, 11th, and 12th cranial nerves
The second case was a 53-year-old man with abnormalities of the 5th, 7th, 9th, 10th, and 12th cranial nerves
In both, magnetic resonance imaging revealed a ring-like area of abnormal signal intensity surrounding the carotid artery at the skull base
Carotid angiography was consistent with the suggestion of dissection on the magnetic resonance studies in both cases
Internal carotid artery dissection may thus present with multiple cranial nerve palsies, which could be mistaken for an infiltrating tumor of the skull base
Magnetic resonance imaging is useful in identifying the condition
